title: British travel blogger and her boyfriend freed from hellhole Iranian jail
text:

A British travel blogger and her boyfriend have been freed from a hellhole Iranian jail.

Jolie King and her Australian partner Mark Firkin were reportedly arrested for flying a drone without a licence in Iran's capital city, Tehran.

They were detained on spying charges in the notorious Evin prison where British-Iranian mum Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe is languishing.

But Australian foreign affairs minister Marise Payne today confirmed: "It is with some enormous relief that I announce that they have been released and returned."

"Scared and disorientated" Miss King was locked in solitary confinement in the jail.

The couple, who live in Perth, have been blogging about their mammoth road trip around the world since leaving Australia in 2017.

The pair, who have 19,000 Instagram followers, are said to have been filming footage for their YouTube channel and their families insisted the arrest was a "misunderstanding".

Miss King, it is claimed, was being used by Iran as a bargaining chip to secure the release of an Iranian prisoner in the US.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe's husband Richard previously said Miss King has been left "scared and disorientated" by her interrogations in the jail.

He said: "I know that the girl is now in with Nazanin, [she] came through scared and disoriented and obviously had been quite intimidated by being interrogated for all that time in solitary [confinement].

"In solitary, the only people you see in there are your interrogators and their job is to terrify you."

The couple's families reportedly claimed their arrests were due to a "misunderstanding" because they did not know about Iran's strict drone laws.

Pouria Zeraati, editor of the London-based Manoto TV, a Persian language channel, said the country bans anyone from flying a drone without a licence.

He said: “The family says this was a misunderstanding and Jolie King and her fiance Mark Firkin were unaware of the Iranian law which bans drone flights without a licence."

Australian foreign affairs minister Ms Payne said a third person - British-Australian Kylie Moore-Gilbert - remains detained in Iran, Ms Payne added.

She has been locked away for more than a year having reportedly been handed a 10-year sentence.

(Image: PA)

"Very long-term negotiations" were taking place to secure the release of the Cambridge-educated academic, Ms Payne added.

Ms Moore-Gilbert was most recently a lecturer in Islamic Studies at Melbourne University.

Earlier, Iran's semi-official news agency Fars reported that the Islamic Republic's judiciary spokesman Gholam Hossein Esmayeeli confirmed all three - Miss Jolie, Mr Firkin and Ms Moore-Gilbert - were detained for spying.

A statement released by Mr Firkin and Miss King's families said at the time their names became public: "Our families hope to see Mark and Jolie safely home as soon as possible."
description: Jolie King and her Australian partner Mark Firkin were arrested for allegedly flying a drone without a licence in Iran's capital, Tehran
